node.text: Perhaps the question I get asked the most is ‘how do I shift to living a life of purpose?  I think the answer lies in the fact that we often lead our lives by asking the wrong question.  We ask: "How do I make a living?", instead of asking “How do I make a life?” We vote for a "living wage" instead of voting for a  candidate willing to give us a “living future”; we wonder what the world owes us instead of figuring out how to give more to those around us. Like a net we cast around us, the path to a life of purpose can be found when we find the confluence of 4 things: 1)the thing that you love, 2)the thing that you are good at, 3) the thing that gets you paid and d) the thing that the world needs then we can find our life’s purpose. When you answer these four questions, in the middle you will find your IKIGAI, or sense of purpose.  I hope this reflection helps you think about how to live a more purposeful life in 2020! Scroll to the next slide to learn more about this ancient Japanese concept and tag someone who needs help finding their IKIGAI. #Ikigai #purpose #nākāmākai

A gentle snow flurry covers the firs and spruces that line up the shores of the Fishing Branch River in the Yukon, while a Grizzly bear searches for one last salmon for the day. Whether you celebrate Christmas, Hanukkah, Kwanzaa or just the beauty of nature on this winter day, may it be full of love, family and peace.  Feed your soul today.  Reach to another human being for love. Feel connected to the things you care about.  Dare imagine a more peaceful, caring world.  I will be doing the same. With @paulnicklen. Much love and gratitude for all the friendship on this beautiful day.

#holidays #love #family #nature #christmas #hanukkah #kwanzaa

This year, I am giving the gift of the #TheTide to each of my kids. All of our lives depend on a healthy and abundant oceans, but children born near the water are among the first of us affected by climate change as sea levels rise around the world. I cannot sleep at night sometimes, knowing that some of them will probably become climate refugees in my lifetime, in my children's lifetime, and that, because of this impending crisis, borders in some parts of the world will be tragically closed off. Our children are the future; we have to do better for them. I want to make sure that @SeaLegacy's message is heard in every home, political office, and on every international stage. #TheTide is the vehicle that is going to help us get there. Join me in giving the gift of #TheTide this holiday season; go to the link in my bio to send a loved one the chance to be a part of the solutions and to come behind the scenes on expedition as @PaulNicklen and I do everything we can to change the narrative for our world's oceans.

@IvanaCook floats above a garden of coral off the coast of Mo'orea in French Polynesia, where we spent time free-diving together to document the severe bleaching of the coral reefs on a @SeaLegacy assignment. As part of the @CoralGardeners, she photographed the reef restoration work that @toutiess and all the other members of the organization do to restore the reef on the island that is also their home. Together, these young people are transplanting species of coral that have survived bleaching events onto parts of the dying reef - to save it, and the ocean life that depends on healthy reefs for survival. If you're looking for an alternative Christmas gift this holiday season, go to the link in my bio to support these incredible kids, and #AdoptACoral in a loved one's name to help rebuild the coral reef on Mo'orea. #WeTheReef #TurningTheTide

Collaboration is a crucial part of the work that we do at @SeaLegacy. When @PaulNicklen and I first co-founded @SeaLegacy, we knew that we were trying to accomplish something so big that we simply couldn't do it alone. Our dream is to bring the far corners of the ocean closer to those who might never get a chance to experience its wonder firsthand and to give people an opportunity to participate in conserving it. Thanks to our incredible network of allies and every member of #TheTide, SeaLegacy has grown beyond our wildest dreams. We also have an incredible team behind us, supporting us every step of the way. I recently returned from an unforgettable expedition in Timor-Leste with @PaulNicklen, @Andy_Mann, @samkretch, @fizzyfarfaraway, @ryantidman, and @kyle.roepke. The expedition would not have been possible without the support of @zodiacwatches. We're premiering exclusive content on their channel in January 2020 - follow them now so you don't miss it!⁠
⁠

While her massive mom slept below us, this baby sperm whale just wanted to play. I couldn’t believe how engaged and curious she was! April, The Little Mermaid, as she is known, with her 20-foot-long and approximately 6,000 pound physic was adorable, yet intimidating .  I don’t know what it is about him, but as I have seen it happen before with leopard seals, bears and sea lions, all she wanted to do was play with @paulnicklen. He was laughing so hard his mask was flooding! This was nothing short of a magical interaction. There was a hint of adrenaline to have an animal so interested in you, there is a large dose of awe and there is a massive dose of gratitude because these are once-in-a-lifetime experiences.  It is so important that countries like Dominica understand the value of a blue economy.  They  are working to share what it means to run ethical wildlife tours.  Shockingly, there are still countries who actively kill whales, orcas and dolphins for food and bait. Imagine the income they would earn if they ran low impact whale watching instead! A whale is worth a lot more alive than it is dead and it is certainly worth a lot more in the wild than in captivity. Thank you all for an incredible year and for following our journey with @sealegacy.  We have grown a lot and we are now a team of 30 (and growing). 2020 will be a pivotal year for our oceans and I cannot thank you enough for joining the Tide and for helping us change how the story ends.  Head to @paulnicklen  to see images of this special encounter. All photos taken on special research permit with the Dominican Government.  With @perneiro_spermwhales.  Please #follow @paulnicklen and @sealegacy to see more from this encounter.  #gratitude #nature #naturelovers.🐳🌊

When you give someone the gift of #TheTide this holiday season, you're really giving them an opportunity to join a global community of powerful ocean advocates. The strength of the Tide is in the hands of its members. Together, we have lit beacons for an #OilFreeLofoten; we have stood up against big industry to say #NoPebbleMine; we were instrumental in the fight to #BanDeathNets in California, delivering over 100,000 signatures to US Senators Dianne Feinstein and @kamalaharris; and we helped sway the vote in favor of mako sharks earning a critical @CITES Appendix II protection. And we're only getting started!! For our first expedition in 2020, I'm headed to Antarctica with @PaulNicklen and our @SeaLegacy expedition team to share stories about why we need to create more marine protected areas in the southern ocean. Go to the link in my bio to join #TheTide, or consider giving a membership to a loved one as an alternative gift this holiday season. Thank you all so much for your love and support. #TurningTheTide⁠
⁠

Titouan Bernicot (@toutiess) told me he was "born on a pearl farm lost in the middle of the Pacific Ocean." At age sixteen, he realized that the coral reefs in French Polynesia were dying and decided to do something to help. He founded @CoralGardeners, a nonprofit that educates the public about the importance of coral reefs. Now 20 years old, Titouan works alongside his fellow Coral Gardeners to restore the reef on their home island of Mo'orea. Spending time with them and my team at @SeaLegacy reinvigorated my own sense of purpose and filled me with hope. You can help Coral Gardeners rebuild their home reef by adopting a coral from their website. Or! Why not #AdoptACoral for a loved one this Christmas as an alternative and eco-friendly gift idea? They will plant a new coral on your behalf, and you (or your loved one!) will receive both a photo and a certificate of your baby coral. Help me help them; let's save the reef together. #WeTheReef #TurningTheTide

A Timorese fisherman is illuminated by a beam of sunlight as he freedives to catch a meal for his family. This man grew up fishing in these waters, learning from his father how to hold his breath for long enough that he turns invisible to the fish that will become his dinner. Timor-Leste has some of the most beautiful reefs I have ever seen. It is a coral biodiversity hotspot with over 250 species of reef fish documented living amongst the pristine coral. This fall, my @SeaLegacy team and I worked with @zodiacwatches to document this incredible ecosystem and learn how we can help ensure that this special part of the world is protected for years to come. Keep an eye on @zodiacwatches' feed for exclusive content from this expedition in January 2020! ⁠⠀
⁠⠀

When my children were still young enough to live at home, I was fortunate to be able bring them with me on some of my travels. Here they are, bored and tired, while I photograph monkeys in the Mata Atlantica of Brazil. Now that they are grown and exploring the world on their own, I am bursting with pride over the incredible, beautiful people all three of them have become. @JohnMittermeier, @Jittermeier, @MickMitty are the most important reasons I do the work that I do. This holiday season, there is a wonderful opportunity to show someone how much you care by investing in the future of our shared earth in their honor. By giving the gift of #TheTide, you will send them behind the scenes on expedition with @PaulNicklen, me, and our @SeaLegacy team and they will get to be a part of our conservation work. Go to the link in my bio to learn how to give this special gift to your loved ones this year.⁠⠀
⁠⠀

The hardest part of my job as a photographer is to be away from home, especially around the holidays. Whenever I have to be away, I love leaving a little bit of myself behind in the form of images and stories so that those I love know that I am working as hard as I can to make our planet a better place. The #NestHub allows me to share what I am shooting with them in almost real-time! I make a Live Album, add images and voila! It’s like the people at home are on the journey with me, experiencing what I’m experiencing through the pictures I’m creating in the field. Love it!! Images: 1) at my home in British Columbia, with an egg yolk jellyfish on #nesthub 2) at the North Pole 3) in the Great Bear Rainforest 4) in Cuba’s Gardens of the Queen 5) in Tamil Nadu, India

Anyone who travels a lot for work understands how hard it is to stay connected with family and friends on different time zones. My career and conservation work demand a lot of my time and while I love my job, I love it even more when I get to share time with the people I love. @Andy_Mann is not only an exceptional artist and friend, he is also one of my favorite humans. I call him a Human of the Ocean and I love diving with him! Recently, we traveled together with @SeaLegacy to the small southeast Asian country of Timor-Leste, where we were invited by their government to tell a story about biodiversity and the potential to support the creation of a blue economy in the area. Andy's work ethic and sense of humor made our time in this beautiful community that much more memorable. Thank you to @zodiacwatches for making this important expedition possible. If you aren't already, follow @zodiacwatches so you don't miss exclusive content from our expedition, premiering on their page in the new year! January 2020!

They look small, but trust me, they are fairly large!  A “mother and daughter” ballet captivated me under the tropical blue skies of the Caribbean. I truly loved the time I spent with this group of Sperm whales in Dominica.  @paulnicklen and I had a blast hanging out with this baby whale and her family. Her name is Ariel, “the Little Mermaid” and she is absolutely not afraid of people.  On the contrary, she is smart and curious. Whenever her mom and aunties (yes, these are matriarchal societies) would try to take a nap, she would come up to the surface to check us out.  I hope you will come back over the next few days to see more images of this beautiful baby whale and learn more@about the complex social lives of these beautiful creatures .  With @sealegacy @perniero__spermwhales and @silvioscagliahaart.  Makes me think of my @Jittermeier

The best way to find hope is by taking action. Threatened by climate change, pollution, and destructive fishing practices, coral reefs are in decline in most parts where they exist. In French Polynesia I met an incredible group of young people who inspired in me so much hope for the next generation of conservationists. In this photo, 20 year old Titouan Bernicot (@toutiess) tends one of the coral gardens off the coast of Mo'orea. Titouan and the other @CoralGardeners work to restore the reef on the island that is also their home. If you're looking for a sustainable Christmas gift this holiday season, go to the link in my bio to support the incredible work of the @CoralGardeners and #AdoptACoral in a loved one's name! If enough corals are adopted, they will be able to create a new coral reef on Mo'orea. #WeTheReef #turningthetide

Holding onto the rocks with one hand and gripping my camera with the other, I could hardly believe how strong the currents are in the remote island of Darwin. As I fought to maintain my position, waiting for the school of hammerhead sharks that often patrols these waters, I was surprised when this hieroglyphic hawkfish (Cirrhitus rivulatus) just floated over to where I was and “sat” on the rock right in front of my dome.  The sharks I was looking for never appeared on this dive but I enjoyed studying the beautiful patterns on this colorful reef fish of the Galapagos

This is the story behind the image of the Lady with the Goose, and why I chose it for the cover of Amaze, my fine-art book. Selecting photographs for a book like Amaze is an incredibly personal experience. It is both exhilarating and humbling because you know that one day these images are going to live in someone's home; maybe on a mantelpiece or as a part of a collection of other fine-art books. Every image in Amaze has a story that resonates with me, and I hope that they inspire you - to dream, to act, to feel. The world is such a beautiful place. I think it is important for us to remind each other of that sometimes. If you'd like a copy of Amaze for yourself or for a loved one, there are signed copies available at the link in my bio.  Otherwise, the book is also available at Amazon. Thank you for supporting my art!

I love how people travel in the Amazon.  We came across this small family of Wai Wai women on the Essequibo River in Guyana.  Deep in the heart  of the Amazon, the only mode of transportation is by boat and most people make their own vessels by carving a dugout canoe out of a large tree.  My favourite part of this photo, of course, is how at ease the dogs are.  People in the Amazon keep dogs as hunting companions and as an alarm against forest predators, like jaguars. With @JennygNichols

I watched as hunters brought the dead mother of this baby to the village.  They had shot her with arrows and she was destined to feed the many hungry mouths in the village.  From her arms, a baby monkey had been pried and still alive, it was also brought to the village.  One of the kids claimed it as a pet and for the next couple of days, the baby monkey clung to the boy’s hair, who tried to feed it small pieces of fruit and seeds,  until either because of the shock of losing its mother or simply because it was too young to survive on its own, he too died.  I always feel very helpless when confronted with what seems like cruelty and disregard for suffering and I often have to remind myself that people that survive by scratching a living from the jungle and who live thousands of miles away from any other civilization, live by a different set of rules.  I try not to impose my own values and opinions on their lives as I have no idea of what suffering and privations they too must undergo.  The more time I spend with indigenous people the more I realize that they are not cruel, as they take no joy or pleasure in seeing animals suffering, they are just surviving and we cannot judge them for that. That doesn’t mean my heart doesn’t break for this baby monkey. #worldmonkeyday @chamiltonjames

A couple of years ago I heard about a humpback whale that got entangled in the anchor ropes of a salmon farm in BC.  I was horrified to learn there was only one person trained to disentangle whales in the whole coast of Western Canada. By the time he got there, eight hours later, the whale had died. With @sealegacy we decided to invest in training some of the people living in remote indigenous communities along the coast to disentangle whales. Episode 5 is the last one in @SeaLegacy's new 'Entangled' series, and it is also my favorite because it showcases how a team of Kitasoo First Nations watermen and women in British Columbia have learned how to help animals in distress. The community of Klemtu is fast becoming a world class ecotourism destination and they need their whales alive!! Over 300,000 whales and dolphins die globally each year due to entanglement in fishing gear or marine debris. Your donation to @sealegacy will help us train and support more communities to help animals in distress. Please, go to the link in my bio to watch the full series and become a member of The Tide to help us train more people. 
#video #videooftheday #fishing #whales #humpback #extinctionendshere #turningthetide #oceans #entangled  #beautifulBC #explorebc

In our western arrogance and our cozy relationship with all the privileges that colonialism has afforded us, we find it easy to forget, or to pretend it doesn’t exist, or maybe that it is a fairy tale, but trust me when I tell you, indigenous people are still connected to the operating system of our planet and they know a thing or two about survival.  Their knowledge of both the pronounced and the nuanced changes that climate change is causing on Earth cannot be ignored. Not because they deserve a seat at the table, but because they may hold the key to save us from ourselves. Full Indigenous participation at global international meetings, like the recent Conference of the Parties in Spain, is critical to change the dominant narrative by bringing in traditional knowledge and perspectives for climate change mitigation. Without indigenous participation by Indigenous Peoples, there can be no true lasting action. Global forces are pushing for the West to stop seeing Mother Earth as a resource to be exploited and instead revere her as a source from which all that is good and bountiful originates and to which we are all connected.. For the next 24 hours, I will donate 25% of every sale of both regular and limited editions of my book Amaze, which celebrates the beauty and knowledge of indigenous cultures to my favourite indigenous organization @NiaTero.  If you don’t follow them, make sure to give them some love #Amaze Link in my bio.

One thing that @paulnicklen and I have learned as we navigate the tumultuous world of social media, is that if you are going to share an emotional, heart-wrenching photograph or video, you better also share a way for people to participate and be activated to make things better.  Our oceans are facing so many challenges and we cannot do it alone.  We are lucky to have created The Tide, our online activation community, to help us face these challenges together, as a community. On the day we encountered this entangled whale, we knew we would have to dive deep into the solutions for the global problem of marine mammal entanglement.  The good news is there are many.  All you have to do is head to the link in my bio and become part of positive change.  I am not peddling hope nor desperation, I am offering all of us a way forward. Thank you for being part of the most important journey: the one we all share as citizens of planet Earth!

I dream of an ocean where all of the ghost nets left behind by hundreds of years of industrial fishing are no longer “out of sight out of mind”; only remembered when dead whales or dolphins make headlines for washing up on shore, after drowning in abandoned or lost gear. Can whales and crab fishing co-exist? Despite what our gut reactions might be after witnessing something as devastating as a humpback whale entangled in a line from a crab pot, innovations in fishing technology and new policies are really hopeful signs. As recently as this November, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife made a commendable decision to delay the opening of commercial Dungeness crab season after aerial surveys showed the presence of humpback whales in the area. And a lawsuit from 2017 was put on hold even earlier this year when the department chose to protect the spring whale migration by closing the crab fishery three months ahead of schedule. Small teams of people are scouring the bottom of the ocean to remove abandoned crab pots. @SeaLegacy and I are working with organizations innovating in alternative fishing gear to help make our world's oceans a little bit safer for whales everywhere. Geoff Shester, Senior Scientist at @Oceana, explains in episode 4. Go to the link in my bio to watch!

Thank goodness there are trained people to help entangled whales!! Peggy is the co-founder of Monterey's Whale Entanglement Team and they are the First Responders for whales in distress. I know that everyone who sees an entangled whale wants to go out and try to help it. Of course you do!! But the best thing you should do is to report any entanglement, take some coordinates, and monitor from a distance, while experts, like Peggy, disentangle the animal. Whale disentanglement is complex and dangerous; well-meaning, untrained persons can tragically make an entanglement worse. Research suggests that 300,000 whales and dolphins die each year around the world due to entanglement in fishing gear or marine debris. I am working with my team at @SeaLegacy to raise awareness about this devastating problem. Go to the link in my bio to watch Episode 3 of @SeaLegacy's 'Entangled' series in its entirety!

I like reading the newspaper in the morning before I do anything else. This is one of those habits that lately has me meandering through the day as in a haze of despair and depression; this is especially true when I read the articles that say the Arctic might become ice-free in the summer months for the first time in history as early as next year.  Other scientists debate this and they push the prediction back another 30 years.  Unless we make a real effort to curb emissions, it won’t matter if it is now or a few years down the road. Changes in the Arctic are already affecting polar wildlife, indigenous people and the chemistry and mechanics of the ocean. I know there are many actions we all can and should take every day, including eating a low carbon diet and reducing our reliance on fossil fuel transportation.  What we do with our vote, however, is the most impactful action we can take. We will have the most impact when we show up at the polls and elect politicians that have pledged to take the action necessary to repair our ailing planet. #voteforclimateaction #ukvote #

When my @SeaLegacy expedition team and I came across a humpback whale entangled in a line from an abandoned crab pot in Monterey Bay everything in my world stopped. Even twenty years as a wildlife photographer could not have prepared me for this moment. Unless you're trained on how to properly rescue a whale, it's easy to assume that you could just go out and cut the line but the reality is a very different thing. Approaching a whale in distress without the proper training or equipment is dangerous for everyone involved, especially for the whale. I was shocked by how unprepared I felt. Go to Episode 2 at the link in my bio to see what happened.
